## URL : http://www.epinions.com/content_14736461444
## Topic : Yahoooooo for Yahoo Groups
## Score : 5.0
## Recommended : Yes
I discovered Yahoo Groups back in March 2000 when it was known as Onelist .
A month or so later , the name was changed to eGroups .
Then , in January 2001 , Yahoo took over and the name was changed from eGroups to Yahoo Groups .
The first group I joined was called teen_mamas .
I was 18 years old and about five and a half months pregnant with my first baby .
I had nobody in " real " life who could relate to what I was going through .
I received an invitation from a girl named Mia ( who at the time was 18 and pregnant with her second baby ) to join the email group she created to bring teen moms together .
I took her up on the invitation and joined the list .
Joining that list resulted in meeting girls who would soon become some of my best online friends .
They could relate to me in a way that no one else could .
I quickly became addicted to the idea of email groups and decided to see what other kinds of groups there were .
I soon found out that there was a group related to just about any topic you could think of !
All I had to do was type a keyword into the site's search engine and numerous results would appear .

I became a member of quite a few more groups over the next few months - one called youngmilmoms , for young military moms ( my husband is in the Army ) , one called ebaymamas ( for moms who sell on eBay , and about six or seven others .
I even started two groups of my own .
Yahoo Groups has many different features which make the groups fun to use .
They aren't just for sending email !
The features include :
Polls Members of the group can create polls to survey the group's opinions on any topic .
After voting , the person who created the polls can end them and have the results sent to the members of the group .
Bookmarks Members of the group can add links to their favorite websites so others can find the sites easily .
Database Members of the group can create a database to store information .
Several of the groups I belong to use this feature to create address books for the group members .
Promote Allows members to get the HTML code for a " join " box to put on their personal website to promote the group and recruit new members .
Post Allows you to post messages to the group from the Yahoo Groups website instead of sending the messages from your personal email account .
Files Members of the group can upload pictures from their hard drive to the Files section of the site .
After uploading , a notice is sent to the group stating that a new file has been uploaded , and it includes the URL to the file .
I like this feature because I am still able to view people's pictures , yet my inbox does not get clogged with huge files .
Chat Members of the group can enter the chat area at Yahoo Groups and chat with other members .
I don't particularly like the chat rooms , I find them to be quite slow , but that's just me : ) I know of others who really like this feature .
So as you can see , there are many different features to play around with at Yahoo Groups .
It isn't just an email loop service .
It creates lasting friendships and bonds .
I have made many great friends through the groups I belong to .
I know that if I have a question about something , I can send a message to the group and more often than not , someone will have an answer for me .
Of course , along with the good things , there are usually some bad things .
This is the case with Yahoo Groups .
I find that when I send a message to any of the groups I belong to , it sometimes takes hours or even days for the message to go through to the group .
This can be quite irritating , especially if there is a question I need an answer to right away or if I just need advice about something that has been bothering me .
I'm not sure why this happens .
I know it isn't just my email that's acting up , because many others have complained about the same thing .
And of course , Yahoo can't tell us why this is happening .

I don't really think it has anything to do with the switch from eGroups to Yahoo Groups because the delay in messages has been happening ever since I first joined a group ( back in the day when it was still called Onelist ) .
Even though the message delay can be quite irritating , I still love Yahoo Groups .
I love signing on to find my inbox crowded with 300 messages : ) As a stay at home mom , I don't get much adult conversation , so the mass amount of email I get makes up for that .
I can talk to my online friends at any time of day or night , and reach a number of them with just one email .
All in all , I have been very satisfied with my experiences with the email lists .
I would definitely not hesitate to recommend the services at Yahoo Groups .

## Topic : Egroups to Yahoogroups , it's all the same !
## Score : 4.0

I've been a member of Egroups ( now called Yahoogroups , formally called Onelist ) for almost four years .
Even with all of the mergers and changes it has gone through over the years , Yahoogroups is still one of my all-time favorite places on the Internet .
How does it work ?
First , you need to set up an account with Yahoo .
Once you go to the site www.yahoogroups.com , it will walk you through setting up an account .
Once this is done , you can begin searching for groups that pertain to your interests .
Subscribing to the group you choose is as easy as clicking " subscribe " .
What do you mean by GROUPS ?
They are e-mail groups .
For example . . . you want to join a group that is called parenting of babies born in 1999 .
If you find a group exists , you join it , and will start receiving emails from the people in that group that are sent to the group's email address .
You can receive individual emails , digests ( a group of 25 email messages in one big message ) , or you can opt to read them right from the web .
All the people in this group have babies born in 1999 , so that is the " common link " that brought you all together .
Can I create my own groups ?
Yes , and it is quite easy to do !
I have a few of my own , and they are easy to create .
First , you pick a name for your group .
Yahoogroups will walk you through step-by-step on helping you place your group so it is easy for others to find .
There is a place to describe your group , which will be seen by others .
This helps them decide if your group is right for them .
Once that is done and you set up the email address ( which would be YourGroupName@yahoogroups.com ) , then you can modify your group's home page .

The options offered include , but are not limited to : moderated or not ; listed or not ; invite only or direct subscribe ; archived messages ; color choices ; file uploads ; and other added bonuses such as database entries , and group polls ( to get a general idea of what the members in your group would enjoy , or just to get their opinions on fun things ) .
Is there anything else I should know ?
The service is free .
You can sign up for as many groups as you like , and make as many as you like .
A lot of groups out there have tons of email come in each day , so if you don't have a big mail box , I wouldn't join too many right away until you know what you and your ISP can handle !
There is nothing to download and nothing to upgrade .
Just be on the lookout for the name changes !

## URL : http://www.epinions.com/content_10439528068
## Topic : Not everyone cried " Yahoo ! "
at the demise of eGroups
## Score : 5.0
## Recommended : Yes
With the purchase of egroups by Yahoo !
came the depressing realization that the little fish can't compete with the sharks .
Yahoogroups did a relatively competent job of merging the two companies .
However , unlike the merger between onelist and eGroup , all eGroup members had to convert their user information into a Yahoo ID .
( Previously , onelist members used their onelist ID and eGroups members used their eGroups ID . )
I had a few eGroup IDs .
My home email is only used for my 'family reunion' site , while other emails are utilized for my chat room groups and critique circles .
I had to 'marry' each of these eGroup accounts with a Yahoo !
ID .
This took some time to figure out on my first attempt , just to get the message " Sorry , that ID is already in use .
Please choose another . "
Well , I don't want to choose another , thank you very much .
I have been known on the internet as 'bubbly1' for many years , and that is what the other members of my eGroup accounts know me as .
I felt as awkward as I did when I first signed my married surname after marrying my husband .
Now that I am used to my new identities , however begrudgingly , I am impressed that Yahoogroups has tried to maintain the set-up that eGroups had .
All of the sections are there , and no data was lost in the merger .
Another thing that I noticed while using the new merged format is that all of the mail I have received shows the poster's email address .
This was blocked in eGroups .
All mail came from the eGroup e-mail address , not the individual members .

Now that I'm finished my griping about the demise of another great .com by way of mega-corporation ingestion , I'll give you my opinion on the workings of Yahoogroups ( formerly known as eGroups , may it rest in peace ) .
Yahoogroups allows you various options .
You can have your group open to anyone or restricted to authorized and invited members only .
There is a java chat function , a bulletin board ( which emails the posts to the members ) , file gallery , calendar and a poll .
Members can choose whether they want individual emails , a daily digest ( my personal option ) or visit the website to read the missed traffic .
The owner can also have the list moderated , messages approved prior to posting , or s/he can restrict all posting .
This last option works great if you want to use the list as a mailing list for your website .
You can easily advertise your eGroup on your website ( the HTML coding is provided by Yahoogroups ) and have interested parties click a button to join your mailing list .
This save you from having to upload a mail-list editor to your webpage and using space where you could be adding your personal data .
eGroups had a mailing list for moderators and owners .
I'm not positive if Yahoogroups has maintained this communication tool , since I haven't received any mail from this list since the physical merger occurred .
Yahoo !
and eGroups were pretty good about keeping the eGroup moderators up to date on the progress of the merger .
I felt comfortable with the measures they were taking to protect my lists , even though I still didn't like the idea of Yahoo !
taking over .
When the merger finally went through , they created an easy to use converter for your accounts .
Well , easy if your ID wasn't already taken , as was my case .
Basically , Yahoogroups is an effective communication tool for sharing ideas and files , but the interface is slow due to the inherent slowness of its bulletin board format .
Although there are many groups you could join , this can also be a drawback .
Finding the exact fit may take a lot of trial and error .
Also , you may find that there are a lot of groups that are not appropriate to all members of your household .
A child filter or close parental supervision should be used .
## URL : http://www.epinions.com/webs-review-199F-9FAC71F-394452D0-prod6
## Topic : ONE LIST : FUN AND INFORMATIVE
## Score : 5.0
## Recommended : Yes
EGROUPS , now known as ONELIST , is both fun and informative for me .
I belong to 3 groups at the present time .
These groups are MCTD/UCTD , FIBROMYALGIA-CFS and FREE4Us .
First I'll explain a little about what Egroups are .
Egroups/Onelist are groups of people who share a common interest .
You communicate with other members of the group by posting E-Mails .
Whether its a question your wanting an answer to or a fact you'd like to share .
Its all done the same way .
By sending an E-mail everyone in the group you have selected gets the E-mail .
Egroups/Onelist has many different catagories for you to find something your interested in .
From WRESTLING to other sports , From Health topics to Freebies .
You'll find the groups listed by interest on the home page .
Find one your interested in , join the group and your on your way to getting E-mail you'll WANT to get .
My first group is very helpful to me when it comes to dealing with my medical problems .
MCTD/UCTD is a group of people who either have or have a loved one who has these health problems .
MCTD is Mixed Connective Tissue Disease , UCTD is Unidentified Connective Tissue Disease .
This covers health problems such as LUPUS , ARTHRITIS , FIBROMYALGIA and other similar diseases .
Its wonderful if you find yourself newly diagnosed with any of these diseases .
The members of the group can identify with your fears , being they TOO experience what your facing .
There have been many days I have been faced with depression trying to get through yet another day of pain all over my body .
In just a couple of minutes I can send one E-mail and reach 100 people who can help me through my bad day .
Members share with each other new medical information if something is released .
The same is true for the FIBROMYALGIA group .
Fibromyalgia is a condition that effects individuals very differently .
Is hard for you to find a perfect treatment that will keep your pain and fatigue under control .
Members share the experiences they have when facing this condition .
Its great whether your new to Fibro . or have been dealing with it for years .
It saves me a tremendous amount of time .
If Im looking for new information on either Fibro or MCTD , which I have both of , I just ask the group .
The other members E-mail the group any links to new information they have received or found .
I not only benefit from the information but , so does the whole group .
At times I have received new information from friends and can share with all the members of the group with just ONE E-mail posted to the group .
While I do sometimes have fun with these groups , the most fun comes from the group FREE4Us .
This is a group who search the web for FREE offers .
FREE offers such as Samples , Gifts , Coupons , FREE Internet Services and much more .
I get excited if I find a FREEBIE on the web that I know no one else has found .
I share it with the group , again with sending ONE E-mail .
A lot of the members of this group do this all year long saving their freebies for Christmas time .
The MOTO of the group is " IF ITS NOT FREE,ITS NOT FOR ME " .
I really have fun with this group .
Everyone is very helpful and nice .
With your groups at Egroups/Onelist you have a choice , for each group , of how you want to get your E-mails .
You can either choose to get individual e-mails or receive them in digest form .
Choosing individual means you'll receive the e-mails as they are posted , one at a time .
The Digest E-mails means you'll receive the E-mails in one E-mail that contains several messages , usually 10 to 25 messages .
I like the Digest form best .
For me its easier to handle than getting 25 to 50 , sometimes more , e-mails a day .
There have been a couple of groups Ive joined that I have dropped from my list .
Thats because I didnt receive anything from them in one whole week .
These were two Wrestling groups I chose that were small , 10 to 15 members each .
I've found that the smaller groups are not very active .
The larger groups , 70 to 100 or more , are definitely active .
I've received e-mail digests at least once a day since I've joined them .
If your having trouble finding a chat group that participates in a topic your interested in then Egroups/Onelist may be your answer .
I know of some who are members of as many as 20 different groups .
I'm not up to handling that many .
Its all I can do to handle the 3 I have joined but,thats me .
If you have not visited the Egroups/Onelist site before , I'd like to suggest you give it a try .
Its FREE , its easy to use , its easy to join the groups , its all around easy .
For me its been both informative and FUN .
Im sure it will be for you too .

eGroups history .
eGroups was formerly known as " onelist " . . .
This is when I first opened my first group .
They were much smaller , but large enough that I didn't think they would notice if I ran a questionable-material group .
My first list started out with x-rated cartoons .
You know the kind .
Office humor , toilet humor , and eventually some anime .
When onelist announced it's merge with Egroups , I started wondering if they were going to get morals as well , and toss out my list .
So did my list move ?
Nope !
The group was allowed to stay , in fact , I've started a few more lists .
Egroups does have a page that makes you consent to viewing the adult pictures before you can view it the questionable material .
It's a good way for adults to get pictures that they want if they don't have a credit card .
( or if they don't want to put their credit card online .
Draw-backs ?
Of course there are draw backs .
For one , the pictures come in your email , usually one by one .
So , if someone on the list decides to send in 30 pictures one day , that's how many you get .
( unless the owner of the list chooses to spend time to approve each email first . )
Also , if someone puts dozens of pictures into one email , it may block up your email server with your internet providor .
However , Egroups isn't just pictures .
They also have discussions , and up-dates .
On the good hand !
On the good hand , as I mentioned above , you do not need a credit card to access their service .
They are not a porn service , don't get me wrong .
They run many mailing lists .
There are lists for every dog-lover , or stressed out manager , or converstations for military house-wives .
They also subscribe to many magazines , like Cosmo , and Prevention , so you can get only the good headlines if you want .
Your email address has to confirm and approve to every list , so you won't be added to mailing lists that you don't want to be on .
Egroups has never added me to a list I didn't want to be on , or sent me any spam .
( unsolicited e-mail )
The Long Run .
I've been with Egroups ( onelist ) for almost 2 years .
They have always been a reliable service .
They try to prevent spam by only allowing a maximum amount of emails sent per user per day .
They are helpful to web-page developers who want to keep certain people up to date with their changes .
I would recommend Egroups to family members too .
You could use it as a global update .
There are calenders in their web page , where you could put everyone's birthdays and emails would be sent out to remind everyone subscribed to the list .
You can upload family photos , and have everyone notified when there are new pictures to view .
When you send a message to the list , everyone on the list would get that email , instantly .
Egroups VS other mailing services .
To be honest , Egroups ( onelist ) was my first mailing list choice , and I haven't even bothered to look into other services .
This one has everything I need to stay in touch with everyone that I want to .

What this means is that , for example , if janedoe1@aol.com sends a message to hwz1@egroups.com , everyone that is a member of that group will recieve an email from janedoe1@aol.com and will display [hwz1] proceeding the title in the subject line of the email , so that you will know it came from your group .
Your second option is to recieve a daily digest of emails that the group sent out .
With this option , you will recieve a digest of every 25 or so emails that were sent by the group , all added into one email .
And again , beside the Digest number XXX in the subject line , the name of your egroup will be displayed .
Your third option will be to recieve no emails , but to check the posts on the website .
This is not something I would recommend if you want the egroup to work for you , and you really want to become active in your group .
It is much easier to have it sent to your inbox .
The Pros
The positive side of the egroups is that you will meet lots of new people , and if you join an Epinions egroup , you will certainly see a change in your number of hits .
If you join another type of Egroup , like me with weddings , you will find lots of people who are interested in the same things as you and who can offer some great advice !
The Cons
Alright , word of advice .
When you choose your groups , the screen will display how many members are in that group .
If there are 200 members in every group that you join and you join 4 groups , it is very possible that you are going to get about 800 emails per day .
WHAT ? ! !
Yep , I am dead serious , you will get a MASSIVE quantity of emails .
I made this mistake .
I joined three large Epinions groups , one small epinions group , and the large wedding group .
By the end of the day , I had to unsubscribe to two of the Epinions groups and digest one of the large ones , and only recieve individual emails from the smaller one , and my wedding group .
Now , I don't know about you , but finding the time to r/r about 900 Epinions per day and still proceeding with normal daily life and plan my wedding is virtually IMPOSSIBLE .
The Outcome
So , after I learned my lesson , things are going much easier for me !
I have the time to r/r most of the epinions I get the day that I recieve them , and if not , I can catch up the next day .
With my wedding group , it is so much fun , exchanging wedding websites with the girls , and learning about their weddings .
I highly recommend egroups to all of you , but remember the tips about digesting and/or the number of groups you subscribe to !
And one last thing...if you join an Epinions one , you better read just as much as you post ! ! ! !
It is a give and take situation , not a take-take !
Thanks for r/r and Happy Epinionating !

What is Egroups ?
Well Egroups is a free service for those people who wish to create or join a mailing list .
What is a mailing list ?
A mailing list is an email discussion group that uses a single email address to communicate with multiple email addresses .
In other words if you want to share your thoughts about a certain subject you send an email to the discussion groups email address and your email will go to everyone who is subscribed to that group .
This service eliminates the hassle of having to type out a hundred different email addresses for just one email .
The uses of mailing lists
Now that you know what a mailing list is ?
you may be wondering what a mailing list is good for .
Mailing lists are good for those who share a common bond .
For example if you are expecting a baby and you communicate with most of your family through email you can create a mailing list to let your family know how your doctors visit went .
This way you won't accidentally leave anyone out when you send updates on the babies development .
You can also use mailing lists to talk about your favorite TV shows , movies , and actors .
There are even mailings lists are designed as support groups .
Info about Egroups
Well now you know what a mailing list is and what it can be used for let me tell you about Egroups .

t want people to talk about who won the football game last night , you can prevent them from sending ?
off topic ?
emails to your list .

Calendars can play an important part of any discussion group .
Egroups offers this feature to every list .
You can put important dates in the calendar and the list will be notified about this event via email from Egroups .
A 20MB file area is also offered to each mailing list .
This area can be used for files that are too large to be sent through the actual discussion group .
The ability to create and manage polls and an area for links are two more features that are offered to Egroups members .
My final Thoughts
Over all Egroups is a wonderful service that allows you the opportunity to meet new people and share your ideas , thoughts and feelings .
While I think that Egroups is the best server for mailing lists their recent merger with Yahoo has left many Egroups users dissatisfied .
Recently Egroups/Yahoo has decided to place advertisement banners at the top of every email that is sent from their server .
In years past OneList/Egroups has placed these ads at the bottom of every email .
Now in order to remove these ads from the top of the emails you have to pay a $60 yearly fee .
Another pitfall of Egroups is their tech support .

It can take up to 72 hours for them to respond to your problem and chances are they won ?
t respond with the correct solution .
Despite my few complaints Egroups is a wonderful company and I would recommend them to almost anyone .

eGroups is a free email group service , similar to ListBot and CoolList , which is available world-wide , making it easier to join and create groups and meet great people .

So , no matter what your interest is , eGroups sure won ?
t fall short on that !
To sign up for a group , or to create your own , you have to register for eGroups services .
The good thing is that eGroups does not require as much information from you as most web services do .
All eGroups asks from you while registering is your gender , date of birth , country and zip code ( if you reside in the US ) .
Displaying this information to the public is totally optional !
However , if you want other people to get to know you better , you can show this information ( and a lot more ) on your member profile .
Some people may ask you to complete your member profile in full before accepting you into their group .
You also have to reply to a confirmation email to ensure that no one signs you up for junk mail on their own .
JOINING A GROUP
To find a group of your interest you can either search using keywords or browse the directory .
Once you ?
ve found a group you like , just click the subscribe link , choose your membership options and you ?
re done .
It ?
s that simple .
If you subscribe to a busy eGroup with lots of members , your inbox will probably be flooded with hundreds of email for you to wade through everyday .
Doesn't sound too good , does it ?
No Problem !

You can either choose to receive digests ( many messages in one email which are sent in batches of 25 or daily , whichever comes first ) or read the mail directly from the web ( no mail in your inbox ) .
Messages can be posted to the list from the eGroups website as well as from your normal mail program .
CREATING A NEW GROUP

There are three types of groups : Unmoderated groups where members can post freely and all messages are sent immediately , Moderated groups where the moderator approves of each message before it is distributed to the list members , and groups for newsletters or announcements where only the moderator can post messages .
If you want , you can list your new group in the public directory and it will be available for everyone to search for .
If you choose this option you will probably have more members in your group .

However , if you want your group to be private ( e.g . one for your family ) and only want invited people to join ( or attempt to join ) , you'll be better off choosing not to be listed in the directory .

Its really easy to invite people to join your list !
eGroups has a feature which enables you to do so simply by entering the email addresses of those you wish to invite- up to 50 at a time .
You can also directly subscribe members , and not send invitations , but the new members can leave by replying to the welcome email .
If you have a website , you can find the HTML code for a " join group " button on eGroup's website .
Moderators are people who make sure no one abuses the group and everything goes smoothly .
The list owner is usually the only moderator but more moderators can be added .
Each group has a files area in which members can upload files of up to 20MB in total , and up to 5MB each .

These files can be mailed to members , if desired , on subscription , unsubscription , every two weeks or every month , or a message can be sent to the list members announcing the file and they can download it from the website themselves .
You have full control over who joins yout group and , if you want , you can ban obnoxious people from joining .
If you do not want any text or banner ads on messages sent to the group , you can sign up for the No Advertising Option for $4.95 a month .
eGroups has recently been acquired by Yahoo and I sincerely hope that they don ?
t ruin eGroups like they did with Geocities and Webring.org .
But for right now , they're pretty good !

Egroups also allows you to set up polls so you can do surveys ( if you are the moderator ) .
You can set up chats from egroups .
If you want to save the messages for a list you moderate , you can have everything moderated .
There is a data base .

We go to egroups and put in the number of pages we have written that day .
There is so much variety offered through egroups and so easy to use , that it is my main source of lists which I either moderate or belong to .

The egroups I joined are mainly for writers since that is my profession .
I also belong to several craft groups as well .

I have made really good friends just from discussing our lives as writers and mothers .
We help each other on this momwriter list , pray for each other's needs .
It is a very supportive group .
I also learned about online writing markets from being on the momwriters .
And that has earned me money .
I've been included in an anthology , published in web magazines and newsletters all thanks to referrals from other momwriters .
As for friends , I have even met some of my cyber friends in real life .
One came from California to New York where we met and we are going to meet again this summer .
Several others lived in the same state as me and we met at Borders .
BIW ( Book in a Week )
This is not the same as BIW , too .
Another excellent online egroup is book in a week .
Once a month , for one week , we agree to sit at our computers and write .
It has to be something new , not a revision .
We write without revising and turn in our page amounts each day .
Sometimes we have prizes , but most of the time the prize is simply getting the writing done .
This group can be joined at biw@egroups.com.I haven't personally met any of the friends I've made from biw but that doesn't mean we aren't friends .
Several are now listed in my address book and we keep in touch .
Someday we do hope to meet .

Get-It-In-Writing@egroups.com .
This is a group of writers .
We talk about our writing and our books .
We support each other emotionally and sometimes with money when we buy the books of members .
Mainly we encourage each other to complete our writing projects .
If we need help , such as a critique , we can ask if someone is willing .
I do not feel isolated at all from the world .
I feel more a part of the world and extended across the United States , Canada , and even Europe .
I have exchanged gifts with other members of the egroups , holiday cards , recipes .
I really feel we care about each other even though we haven't seen each other .
And that is the plus part .
There is no concern over being too fat , too ugly , too thin or anything else .
We know each other through out words , and those reveal more of our inner self than our appearance can .
My local chapter of Romance Writers of Americas has a list for chat .
Even if I can't go to a meeting I can keep up with what is happening with my friends .
This is a promotional list for authors and writers who want to promote their work .
We also share ideas on how to increase our promotions .
The lists I've mentioned here are some of my favorites and I highly recommend them .
If you aren't a writer , then you should check egroups to find a list you'd like .
I looked up crafts and joined several .
Almost any topic is covered at egroups .
So for me , it is a good thing .

I don't have to bored though .

I quickly learned to prefer the email list over chat rooms for several reasons .

I highly recommend Egroups .
This service has proven to be a large part of my day to day life .
I would really miss these ladies whom I have become close to if I were to leave .

Signing up for egroups is easy .
It's the usual questions about email address , date of birth , gender , zip code , country , agreeing to the term of service , and the option to sign up for other newsletters .
Once you do this and reply to the confirmation email you are set to start joining groups .
Features that are available to groups , but also depend on the owners decisions include file uploading , posting links , a calendar , polls , and archives of messages .
From a moderator/owner perspective egroups gives you complete control over your group .

You can set a welcome message , set a footer on each email that is sent through the group , choose whether or not to archive messages , set moderators and decide how many privileges they have , decide whether or not to moderate posts and/or group membership , you can set it to where a file is sent to a member on joining , unsubbing , pending membership and more .
Also for each member you can set how they receive their mail , whether their posts are moderated , and/or ban them .
There are many more features , but unless you want this review to double or triple in size I better stop LOL .

Sometimes mail is a bit slow going through .

Really the only thing I wish they would change is maybe to have you set an alternate address that they can use to notify you if messages sent to you have bounced .

I didn't realize that my account needed resetting because I didn't even know my mail had bounced .
Finally I went to send a message to a group about " why is it so quiet ? "
and I got an email from egroups saying they couldn't deliver my message because my account needed to be reset .
It wasn't a problem *to* reset , just click on a link in the email and it was done...I just wish there was some way for me to have been notified 10 hours earlier that I needed to do this .
All in all I love egroups .
I am hopelessly addicted .
Maybe there needs to be an Egroups-Anonymous group .
Then again it'd probably be hosted on egroups : )

Nearly 2 years ago , quite by accident , I stumbled upon Onelist.com .

Initially I joined 23 support groups for stay-at-home-moms .

I have since unsubscribed from all 23 of those groups I joined that first month , but have opened quite a few of my own and have joined many others .
eGroups offers flexibility and freedom to come and go as you please .
You can subscribe to a group and receive either individual emails or digest that holds up to 25 individual posts .
The individual email version is just as it states .
You receive each email as it is posted to the group .
However , with each email comes a banner ad from the supporters that pay for you to use eGroups without having to pay .
The digest version contains 25 posts sent to the group that day .
You get less email in your inbox , but the digests are a bit more difficult to read .

I also have opened a few of my own email lists at eGroups .
As an owner you have the freedom to create a list that is just the way you like it .
You can leave a group open so that people can join freely or you can make it a list that each member wanting to join has to be approved by the owner or moderator .

There are many other features that eGroups offers .

There are many categories under which you can subscribe .
Check out eGroups today and find a group that is right for you .
## URL : http://www.epinions.com/content_28692418180
## Topic : The Politics of Yahoo : A Review of Yahoo Groups ( Formerly Egroups )
## Score : 5.0
## Recommended : Yes
Since Epinions seems to be the last place on the planet to find out that Yahoo has taken over Egroups , I have to put the opinion under the old name .
Hmm .
So you like birdwatching , but no one in your family does ?
Go to www.yahoogroups.com and search for birdwatching .
You will find at least one group - an probably more - of people that share your interest .
The premise is simple : a Yahoo Group is formed by someone to cover a topic of interest to people .
People come and sign-up for the group .
Anyone who is signed up for the group can send an email which goes through the Yahoo server and out to everyone who is a member of the group .
People can choose to get the emails individually , in bulk in digest form ( up to 25 emails at a clip put into one email ) , or view the group messages from the web .
There is something for everyone at Yahoo Groups .
I am subscribed to groups about Battlestar Galactica , General Hospital , Disney World , Ferrets , and Camping .
I have been in email groups since before Yahoo Groups or Onelist ( One of its predecessors ) , or Egroups ( another predecessor ) was around .
Usually a group would be formed under the generosity of a University's server .
One group I have been in for at least six or seven years now .
And one thing hasn't changed .
If anything , it's gotten worse : POLITICS .
Don't know what I mean ?
No , I'm not referring to this country's elections or anything like that .
Here's a few tidbits to learn what you will be in for in just about any Yahoo Group .
The moderator runs the group .
A Yahoo Group is run by a moderator ( usually the person who formed the group , but not always ) .
Sometimes there are multiple moderators .
The job of these moderators is usually to keep things on-topic to whatever the group is formed for .
Some moderators are looser than others ; some groups allow a broader range of stuff and allow e-conversations to wander off-topic a bit before saying anything .
Others are very heavy-handed and will come down immediately when an off-topic conversation begins .
The moderator is the one who makes the call .
Since it is his or her group , if you disagree your alternative can only be to form your own group .
You can cry " unfair " or " censorship " , but the bottom line is that it is that person's group to run as he/she sees fit .
Emotions don't translate well in cyber-space .
If someone says something and is joking , better let people clearly know that it is a joke .
Sarcasm doesn't always come across that well and it can cause people to get their hackles up .
In my one group we use [sarc] and [/sarc] to indicate when we're being sarcastic and it's kept it pretty civil .
I have seen people get their feelings hurt all the time in Yahoo Groups .
They open up to their fellow listmates looking for support and end up being treated like dirt .
In one group I was in , a woman opened up about her husband being in a car accident .
She merely asked for people to give their thoughts and prayers to her during that difficult time .

Some of the listmembers took it upon themselves to decide that her actions weren't " appropriate " for someone whose husband had been in a car accident and decided she was a liar and declared this in front of the whole group .
Emotionally , everyone began raking her over the coals and beating her up .
I defended her by saying essentially : So what if she is ?
She is only asking for your thoughts and prayers .
And if you are wrong think of how much more hurt you are piling on her during this difficult time .
But no one could see that side of it because they were so wrapped up in the politics of exposing a supposed liar .
Of course , as soon as I spoke up and defended her they started picking apart everything that I said .
I guess that invited them to have open season on me .
I just left the group .
And this wasn't the first time I'd seen something like this happen .
If you don't like the tone of a group , then leave .
Some groups , while pretending to be one thing , actually have an underlying agenda .
If there is ever anything that makes you nervous about being in a Yahoo Group , I'd suggest you leave .
There are also milder forms of this that don't involve direct prejudice , but people who just want to push their opinion on you and if you think a little differently , you are shunned by the group .
Some of the worst groups out there I have seen are the parenting groups .

Many of them pretend to be there for support and encourage a variety of viewpoints , but they just want a bunch of people together who think alike so they can pat each other on the back about what wonderful parents they are .
If you happen to say that you are raising your child a little differently than they are , then you are wrong , and you are a bad parent .
For this reason alone , I would suggest that you not use your main email address when subscribing to a Yahoo Group .
This makes it much easier to change your email later on should you start getting harassed , threatened , or mail-bombed .
Also , when you join a Yahoo Group it would probably be a good idea to lurk for a week or so to get the general tone and see if it's really for you .
You really don't know who these people are .
Conversations in cyber-space aren't like real life .
People can say and pretend anything .
They can say they are sick , they are dying , they have 10 kids and their husband beats them , and you have no way of knowing exactly what is true .
Have I developed friends on the web and through these groups ?
Yes .
The majority whom I would consider good friends are people I have met in " real life " .
I have gone to sci-fi conventions and met up with fellow sci-fi fans from my groups ; I have gone to Disney World and met up with people who I talked to in groups .
But the bottom line is that you don't know them .
If you are considering meeting someone for the first time , do it in a group setting , or in a public place and don't let them talk you into going for a car ride .
Don't let anyone talk you into sending them money for a plane ticket either .
Just because the two of you supposedly have pet ferrets doesn't mean the supposed 35 year old software programmer isn't a 50 year old psycho-serial-killer
© 2001 Patti Aliventi

## URL : http://www.epinions.com/webs-review-1B58-1115A1A9-39C5CA98-prod3
## Topic : Online Communities galore .
## Score : 4.0
## Recommended : Yes
Since the Internet's expansion began and it joined the mainstream ( or was it the other way around ? )

, ways were looked for so that many people could communicate with each other through e-mail ; simple CC'ing ( carbon copy , a feature that lets you send identical mails to more than one recipient at a time ) was not nearly adequate for the purpose of new users added , old ones having the option to no longer receive mails from a list that outlived its usefulness for them , or anyone at all who wanted to have a historical view of everything sent , by thread or date .

The answer to this need was mailing list , and various Unix-based utilities were soon developed to fill in the niche ; however , they were still somewhat difficult to use , text-based , and with too many parameters and options for the casual non-technical user .
Egroups is , of course , more than a simple web version of a mailing list .
However , where it performs this particular task , it does so with great efficiency , reliability , and through an easy to follow Web interface .
Once you join for free , answering the ( these days obligatory , but to a lesser extent than some sites out there ) series of questions about yourself , you are ready to roll .

There are literally hundreds of discussion lists you can enlist directly , dealing with pretty much everything under the sun , from playing online games on the Internet to tending to your garden , or criticizing a variety of books by theme , author , or book cover colour .
In addition , you can create a new discussion group within 5 minutes , customizable to the degree that you wish it - do you want everyone to be able to join it ?
Would you wish to authorize new additions to the list seperately , or just every mail they send seperately before it's posted ?
Or maybe just allow some recipients of your list the right to post freely , or even allow them to authorize new users altogether ?
There are virtually dozens of options and combinations to cover even the most demanding and specialized needs .

In order to participate in discussions , users may either simply use their e-mail clients , sending mails and replies to the address designated by the Egroups server , or log on the Web site itself and post or read older postings directly from its sleek interface - it is quite well designed to take you where you wish within a couple of clicks , even if are part of a dozen groups .
This is not to say there are no problems .

Sometimes , e-mails take a couple of hours before they show up after they are sent ( although usually they appear in your mailbox before a full minute passes ) ; there are a couple of bugs as well , as for instance I found myself unable to remove my account from its administrator status flag on a group , while I had no problems doing so on a second one .
The advertisements and banners are also at the top of every e-mail sent , instead of the bottom as in many other similar free services on the web , and that sometimes becomes a nuisance .
All in all , when it comes to online communities , this is a highly recommended site .
It will do what you want it to , and it will rarely fail at its focal point .
If you need e-mailing lists it can be your answer .

## Topic : It's Like Being A Part Of A Family !
## Score : 5.0

I had been a member of Onelist for about a year when they announced that they were going to become a new service called eGroups .
So for the past few months , I've been a member of eGroups , and I'm enjoying every part of it !
How does eGroups work ?
eGroups is a great service for people who like the interaction of chat rooms , but don't want to spend time in a room .
Basically , you go to www.egroups.com and register .
Once you are registered , you can sign up for any number of groups .
These groups communicate via email .
You post a message to the group by sending an email to group name>@egroups.com
. Your message is then sent to all the subscribed members
. They , in turn , can reply to your message or post one of their own
. All messages are sent with the list name in the subject line , so you can keep track of several lists at once
. I personally have set up different folders in Outlook for my eGroups lists so that the emails automatically sort themselves according to list name
. Who can join a group
? Anyone can join eGroups the service , but some groups are restricted
. This means that some lists are available to those over 18 or over 21
. Some have open subscriptions , which mean anyone can sign up , and some lists must authorize you to subscribe
. The restrictions are decided by the List Moderator
. Who is the List Moderator
? Anyone can start a list
. You just fill out a simple form with all the information about your group , like name and the purpose of your group , and submit it
. Voila
! You're now a list moderator
. You have the power to make the final decision . you can make restrictions for your list , and even unsubscribe people who don't follow the rules you set for your list
. It's all upto you
. What kind of groups are available
? You name it , and most likely , someone has started a list for it on eGroups
. There are lists for recipe exchanges , TV shows , hobbies , colleges and universities , and even XXX groups
. There are literally thousands of groups available

. You can browse through the various categories until you find something that interests you . eGroups also offers a search option , so you can type in the subject you are looking for , and eGroups will return a list of existing groups dealing with that subject
. You can sign up for as many groups as you'd like
. Each group summary tells you how many members are subscribed , and other pertinent information
. What if I don't want to get emails
? You can also view posts from your group on the eGroup's website

. When you subscribe to a list , there is are 3 options offered : you can receive all the individual posts by email , or receive 25 posts in one email known as a digest , or come to the website to read all the posts
. The choice is yours
. If you belong to a group that has a lot of posts , you may want to get the digest version
. It'll keep your mailbox neater
. You can turn your emails off too
. This is helpful if you are going on vacation and don't want your mailbox flooded while you're gone
. Just go to your account page and turn off the emails
. You can turn them back on when you return
Overview I think eGroups is a great idea
. I have met so many new friends through these lists and groups
. I like the interaction without having all the lewd and inappropriate messages that you can get in chat rooms
. ( " looking for a good cyber time ?
" You get the picture .
) You'll meet people with the same interests as yours
. It's nice to open your mailbox and have some mail waiting for you that's about something you're interested in
. If you want to discuss your favorite hobbies with others , try some of the people at eGroups
. I look forward to every new post -- it's like being a part of an online family
